* * *

Nipah is a deadly virus with no known antidote or approved vaccine to fight it.

New Zealanders set to travel to India and around Asia are being advised to avoid bats and touching anything that may have been contaminated by bats, as more airports introduce screening measures for the deadly Nipah virus.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade has released information about Nipah onits [SafeTravel website](https://www.safetravel.govt.nz/ "https://www.safetravel.govt.nz/"), in light of news that several major [Asian airports have begun Covid-style screening on passengers](https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/travellers-being-screened-at-major-asian-airports-after-deadly-virus-detected-in-india/MWICR24WR5ENHN77HMIOTOUDYY/ "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/travellers-being-screened-at-major-asian-airports-after-deadly-virus-detected-in-india/MWICR24WR5ENHN77HMIOTOUDYY/"), in a bid to keep the virus out.

Video footage posted online of an airport in Thailand shows passengers walking through security. Their faces can be seen on large screens showing their body temperatures in real-time.

## What is the Nipah virus?

Two cases of the zoonotic virus – one passed from animals to humans – have been detected in West Bengal, eastern India, since last month.

The virus was first identified in Malaysia in 1998, when an outbreak occurred among local pig farmers. The result was devastating, with up to 105 deaths and the culling of over a million pigs in a bid to stop the spread.

There have been other outbreaks of Nipah in India since then, including in 2001 and 2007 in West Bengal – where the latest cases are from – and in [2018, when 17 deaths were reported](https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/rare-brain-damaging-virus-spreads-panic-in-india-as-death-toll-rises/HEDWFKJETGUPXJCSGWI7QULL4A/ "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/rare-brain-damaging-virus-spread
